docs.lead_paragraph: WITH interest rates lingering at attractively low levels and little land available for new development, the demand for Fairfield County houses continues to be strong, except for homes at the extreme high end of the price scale. A similar fever is evident in the market for condominium apartments. This is in sharp contrast with the rental market, where some complexes are offering concessions to individual tenants and leasing blocks of apartments to corporations as inexpensive substitutes for hotel rooms.

headline.main: In the Region/Connecticut; Fairfield House Prices Jump, but Rentals Mark Time

docs.abstract: Demand for houses in Fairfield County, Conn, remains strong, except at extreme high end of price scale; demand is also strong for condominium apartments, in sharp contrast to depressed rental market; photo (In the Region/Connecticut) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR decades, many top executives have received the royal treatment at their annual medical examinations -- compliments of their companies. Hospitals and medical centers that offer these so-called executive physicals pamper their patients with breakfast buffets and waiting rooms with many of the trappings of their corner offices: plush carpets, wide-screen televisions, computers and even secretarial help. To make the ordeal of an examination by a retinue of doctors even more palatable, these health care providers often offer the option of combining the medical visit with a golf, tennis or spa vacation.

headline.main: Executive Life; Is a Red-Carpet Medical Exam Better?

docs.abstract: Medical experts say there is little evidence that people who enroll in executive health programs stay healthier or live longer than those who rely on traditional healthcare system; some companies have long provided such pampered programs for top executives to encourage them to have annual exams; photo (M)
docs.snippet: FOR decades, many top executives have received the royal treatment at their annual medical examinations -- compliments of their companies. Hospitals and medical centers that offer these so-called executive physicals pamper their patients with...

docs.lead_paragraph: A growing body of research is leading many medical experts to ask whether more is really better when it comes to health care. Some medical specialties and geographical areas are suffering from a glut of doctors and hospitals, these experts say. Supply seems to drive demand. More hospitals in an area mean many more days spent in hospitals with no discernible improvements in health. More medical specialists mean many more specialist visits and procedures.

headline.main: More May Not Mean Better In Health Care, Studies Find

docs.abstract: Growing body of research leads many medical experts to question whether more is really better in terms of health care; experts say some medical specialties and geographical areas are suffering from glut of doctors and hospitals, and supply seems to drive demand; say more hospitals in area may mean many more days spent in hospitals with no discernible improvements in health; Dr John E Wennberg, leader of research team at Dartmouth Medical School, comments; charts (M)
docs.snippet: A growing body of research is leading many medical experts to ask whether more is really better when it comes to health care.    Some medical specialties and geographical areas are suffering from a glut of doctors and hospitals, these experts say....

docs.lead_paragraph: ON July 2, family and friends of Mrs. Nellie Monk gathered at St. Peter's Church in Manhattan to pay their last respects to the woman who shared most of her life with the pianist and composer Thelonious Monk. Monk and Nellie, as they were known to their friends, were one of the grand couples in jazz. The eulogies reminded us just how critical she was in sustaining her husband's career. She was his personal manager and musical consultant, at times the family's chief wage earner, and mother to their children, Thelonious Jr. and Barbara. After Monk's death in 1982, Nellie Monk helped establish the Thelonious Monk Institute, which promotes jazz through educational programs and competitions, and more recently she was a driving force behind the family record label, Thelonious Records.

headline.main: The Jazz Wife: Muse and Manager

docs.abstract: Robin D G Kelley article on pivotal role wives play in lives of jazz musicians; focuses on Nellie Monk, widow of pianist and composer Theolonious Monk, who died recently, Lorraine Gillespie, widow of trumpeter and bandleader Dizzy Gillespie and Maxine Gordon, widow of saxophonist Dexter Gordon; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DRUGSTORES expect a strong tail wind from an aging population that will take more pills. Like-minded investors see the sector as a handy way to invest in health care, a contrast to pharmaceuticals, an industry where uncertainties abound about new products and political pressures. ''I want to invest in health care long term, through a drugstore,'' said Blaine P. Rollins, manager of the Janus fund, which holds 15 million shares of Walgreen.

headline.main: Investing; A Bet on Drugstores, If Not Drug Makers

docs.abstract: Uncertainties about new products and political pressures that plague pharmaceutical manufacturers do not extend to drugstores that vend their products; investors see drugstores as conservative, handy way of investing in health care sector (M)
docs.snippet: DRUGSTORES expect a strong tail wind from an aging population that will take more pills. Like-minded investors see the sector as a handy way to invest in health care, a contrast to pharmaceuticals, an industry where uncertainties abound about new...

docs.lead_paragraph: IMAGINE that you're sick and your health plan turns you down for treatment you consider essential. For some people, this scene is all too real. In 42 states and the District of Columbia, you can appeal your health plan's decision to an independent reviewer that will evaluate the evidence in your case and make a ruling. Last month, the Supreme Court gave its official stamp of approval to state laws governing that appeal process, ending longstanding uncertainty about its legality.

headline.main: Health Care Appeals Are No Snap

docs.abstract: Michelle Andrews Money & Medicine column on appealing health plans' decisions to deny treatments patients consider essential; notes appeals process is intimidating, complex and chancy, even though 42 states and District of Columbia allow appeals to independent reviewer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Merck & Company said today that its second-quarter profit fell 3.6 percent as costs rose faster than sales, which were hurt by competition from generic copies of its hypertension and heartburn drugs. Net income fell to $1.75 billion, or 77 cents a share, from $1.82 billion, or 78 cents, a year earlier.

headline.main: Costs and Generic Competition Cut Into Merck's Quarterly Profit

docs.abstract: Second-quarter profit at Merck & Co falls 3.6 percent, to $1.75 billion, down from $1.82 billion a year earlier; revenue rises 7.7 percent, to $12.8 billion (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Since the Queens bus strike began a month ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has insisted that the dispute should be settled by the workers and the bus companies and not by City Hall. But now that the 1,500 striking workers and the three bus companies have reached a tentative agreement on health benefits with the city's help, the workers' union is saying that it is up to Mr. Bloomberg to resolve the other big issue in the dispute -- job and pension security.

headline.main: Union and Companies in Queens Bus Strike Turn to City Hall

docs.abstract: Local 100 of Transport Workers Union says it is up to New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg to resolve job and pension security issue in bus strike in Queens now that workers and three bus companies have reached tentative agreement on health benefits with city's help; union leaders worry that some bus workers might be laid off and their pensions endangered if Bloomberg pursues his plan to have Metropolitan Transportation Authority take over Queens bus lines; Deputy Mayor Marc V Shaw says Bloomberg administration is unwilling to promise to safeguard jobs or pensions in event MTA or other companies take over bus operations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gays and lesbians scored a legal victory when the Constitutional Court rejected a complaint by some conservative-governed states that argued that gay marriages contradicted family values enshrined in the Constitution. Under the law, which came into force last August, gays and lesbians are allowed to marry in state registry offices and share common surnames. Their relationships are officially called ''registered life partnerships'' rather than marriages and the law gives couples rights in areas like inheritance and health insurance. Victor Homola (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Victory For Gays And Lesbians

docs.abstract: German gays and lesbians score legal victory when Constitutional Court rejects complaint by some conservative-governed states that gay marriages contradict family values enshrined in Constitution (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate today approved a proposal that could make it easier for Americans to import prescription drugs from Canada, where drug prices are often lower than in the United States. But the Bush administration said it would not carry out the plan because it would endanger public health. The proposal is contingent on a finding by the secretary of health and human services that imports from Canada would pose ''no additional risk to the public's health and safety.''

headline.main: Plan to Import Drugs From Canada Passes In Senate, but Bush Declines to Carry It Out

docs.abstract: Senate approves proposal that could make it easier for Americans to import prescription drugs from Canada, where drug prices are often lower than in United States; Bush administration says plan would endanger public health; proposal would allow only drugs approved by Food and Drugs Administration to be imported (M)
